Award.AbstractNarration:
Pervasive Healthcare Doctoral Consortium 2016

The aim of the Sixth Pervasive Healthcare Doctoral Consortium is to provide doctoral students a supportive scientific forum for students to engage in inter- and multi-disciplinary scholarship focusing on organizational, technical, social, and biomedical issues surrounding health-related technologies. The consortium provide a forum for expert and peer critique of students' doctoral work with the goal of improving their dissertation. Student participants will also have the opportunity to receive networking support and career advice from internationally-recognized experts. Overall, the doctoral consortium brings together people who might not otherwise engage with one another and engage in inter-disciplinary research in fields involving healthcare and pervasive computing. The consortium also exposes participant to different scientific disciplinary approaches and develops the next generation of scholars in pervasive computing in the domain of healthcare.

The aim of the Sixth Pervasive Healthcare Doctoral Consortium is to support doctoral students through constructive remarks and feedback on their interdisciplinary research from prominent researchers and through interaction with other students. Student participants from a broad range of disciplines including pervasive computing, biomedical informatics, computer science, information science, engineering, clinical sciences, law, and medical informatics will give short presentations of their work and receive constructive feedback from five internationally respected experts in pervasive healthcare. The expert panelists will also provide student participants with career guidance and mentoring through presentations and small group advising throughout the day. In addition, the doctoral consortium will be held during pre-conference activities, thus student participants will have the opportunity to see the conference and network with conference attendees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the Pervasive Health 2016 Doctoral Consortium were to: (1) create a cohort of young scholars interested in pervasive health and computing; (2) help young scholars get feedback from a broader professional audience in a supportive environment; (3) challenge students to think deeply about their research and identify areas for improvement; (4) assist young scholars build their network; and (5) provide young scholars with information about research careers for PhDs in pervasive healthcare. To this end, the PI, Katie Siek (Indiana University, USA) and co­organizer, Monica Tentori (CICESE, Mexico) organized a full day doctoral consortium the day before the main conference began. Nine students were selected to participate in the doctoral consortium - 4 from the United States, 2 from Mexico, 2 from the United Kingdom, and 1 from Amsterdam. Five men and four women participated. During the full day doctoral consortium, the following activities took place: (1) students were taught to give 20-­30 second elevator pitches; (2) students practiced their elevator pitches as an introduction to the doctoral consortium; (3) during the main conference, faculty paneists introduced them to senior researchers where they continued to practice their elevator pitches (these activity helped with goals 2, 3, 4, and 5); (4) faculty panelists ­ Katie Siek (Indiana University, USA), Monica Tentori (CICESE, Mexico), Alex Mihailidis (University of Toronto, Canada), and Rosa Arriaga (Georgia Tech, USA) engaged in an hour long panel discussing what they wished they did differently in graduate school, how to prepare for an academic job search, and how to deal with interdisciplinary collaborations (this activity helped with goals 1, 4, and 5); (5) student panelists gave 12 minute presentations providing an overview of their research and the faculty panelists and students provided feedback for 18 minutes (this activity helped with goals 1, 2, and 3); (6) facutly panelists and students went to dinner together to continue discussing their research in an informal setting and industry/research lab faculty panelists and those with research industry experience ­ Mary Czerwinski (Microsoft Research USA), Alex Mihailidis (University of Toronto, Canada), Jesus Favela (CICESE, Mexico), and Nadir Weibel (University of California San Diego, USA) discussed career opportunities in industry and what they look for in interns and future colleauges (this activity helped with goals 1, 4, and 5); and (7) student panelists presented posters at the Pervasive Health poster session during the main portion of the conference to receive feedback from the broader Pervasive Health community (this helped with goals 1, 3, and 4). Based on a post-consortium survey, the young scholar doctoral consortium attendees believed their time was well spent, the panel and networking opportunities were valuable to their development as a scholar, and they received valuable feedback on their research.
